Derek James wrote:

>Okay...here's my suggested format for network XML. 
>(I'm using Colin's recent recurrent XOR network as an
>example):
>
>  
>
[...]

>Neurons need to have a layer designation, denoted by
>the "hint-layer" attribute, and a position within that
>layer, denoted by the "hint-position" attribute.  This
>  
>
OK so the hint-* attributes are needed to generate the SVG output but 
for other purposes they are optional. Perhaps this is where the 
confusion set in elsewhere on this thread.

>that way, you can use whatever logic you like to place
>neurons in any given layer and position, and the XSL
>style sheet can just handle laying them out and
>graphing them.
>  
>
Yes. and if you write your own XSLT or devise some other visualisation 
technique you may choose to ignore the hint-*'s completely and do your 
own layout based purely on the network topology.

>Note that connections need to have an id, as well as a
>"recurrent" attribute.
>  
>
Do you need the ID for your XSLT? I had omitted it from my phenotype XML 
since it's not really relevent. I think the same applies to the 
recurrent flag.

>I'll write a second XSL style sheet to handle the
>transformation from this XML into a form that my
>current style sheet can parse into an SVG image. 
>  
>
[...]

Thanks Derek. This is actually quite useful to me at the moment since I 
didn't have any network visualisation at all until now.


In answer to other queries about other types of information that people 
want storing (and just to reinforce what Derek has already said) - the 
philosophy I would like to see adopted here is to store all experimental 
information including ID's and genomes within the run-xml and 
genome-xml.  If you then wish to pick one of the evolved networks for 
further simulation then you should rebuild the network from the 
available genome-xml.  Right now of course NEAT  uses a direct encoding 
and therefore the network-xml is just the genome-xml with some of the 
attributes and tags missing, this may not always be the case though.

One you have a plain network.xml file (minus the hint-* attributes and 
whatever) you could then load it into a tool that analyses the network 
and inserts hint-* data for the visualisation. Or you might just choose 
to work out the layout 'on-the-fly' as part of the visualisation 
routine, in which case you would never need to store hint-* data.  One 
possibility though is that we create a tool that does it's best at 
laying out the network, but then allows us to manually move neurons 
about with the mouse, we can then save the network-xml with hint-xpos, 
hint-ypos coordinate attributes.

Colin
